titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Dan De Quille Papers
titlestmt.author: by Matthew Daniel Mason

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday January 22, 2019 at 07:15

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: This collection consists chiefly of papers created and collected by Dan De Quille that document a portion of his writing career, circa 1860-1898, as well as a small quantity of material accumulated by his family from 1936 to circa 1956. The papers consist of correspondence, writings, photographs, and ephemera, as well as newspaper clippings collected by De Quille on a variety of subjects.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from the William Reese Company on William Robertson Coe Fund No. 3, 2010.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Dan De Quille Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Dan De Quille Papers. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The description for the collection derives chiefly from a list provided by the dealer, which the processing archivist compared to the collection contents and augmented when appropriate. The material was removed from three-ring binders and rehoused in archival folders and boxes.

bioghist.head: Dan De Quille (1829-1898)
bioghist.p: William Wright (1829-1898), better known by the pen name Dan De Quille, was an American author, journalist, and humorist. He was born in Knox County, Ohio, the oldest of nine children. In 1849, he moved west with his family to West Liberty, Iowa, where he married Caroline Coleman (1829-1912) in 1853. They had five children, two of whom died in infancy. Their surviving children wereMell Wright Evans (1855-1906), Lura "Lou" Gertrude Wright (1856-1928), and Paxson George Wright (1858-1929).

In 1857, Wright traveled alone to California and prospected for gold in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada Mountains and in the Mono Lake region. In 1859, he moved to the silver mining town of Virginia City, Nevada, which extracted its mineral wealth from the Comstock Lode, the first major discovery of silver ore in the United States. In 1862, Wright began writing for the Daily Territorial Enterprise newspaper in Virginia City and adopted the pen name Dan De Quille. He remained on the staff of the newspaper for over thirty years and wrote extensively about the people, events, and mining operations in the region. From August 1863 to May 1864, he supervised the work of Samuel Langhorne Clemens (1835-1910), who adopted the pen name Mark Twain while writing for the newspaper.

In 1874, a group of mine operators in Virginia City approached De Quille to write a history of the Comstock Lode. Working in Hartford, Connecticut, under the editorship of Mark Twain, he wrote A History of the Big Bonanza (American Publishing Company, 1876).
Near the end of his life, De Quille returned to West Liberty, Iowa.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists chiefly of papers created and collected by Dan De Quille that document a portion of his writing career, circa 1860-1898, as well as a small quantity of material accumulated by his family from 1936 to circa 1956. The papers consist of correspondence, writings, photographs, and ephemera, as well as newspaper clippings collected by De Quille on a variety of subjects.

The correspondence in the collection encompasses letters from editors and publishers to De Quille about his writing, as well as a small quantity of letters written by De Quille to his daughter Mell Wright Evans and sister Louisa G. Wright Stevens. There is also a small group of correspondence about De Quille between his granddaughter Irma Evans Morris and Nevada historian Effie Mona Mack in 1936.

Writings by De Quille include a notebook with outlines, drafts, and notes for stories and articles. Other writings include draft manuscripts for articles about Virginia City and California, as well as about Peru, and tales based in the Middle East.

Photographs in the collection include portraits of De Quille and views of his gravesite. Ephemera in the collection includes scrapbook sheets with illustrations that De Quille clipped from magazines and newspapers to present to his granddaughter.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: I. Correspondence, circa 1860-1953. II. Writings, 1876-circa 1956. III. Photographs, circa 1885-circa 1930. IV. Other Papers, 1875-1898.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into three subseries: Correspondence from De Quille, Correspondence to De Quille, and Third-Party Correspondence.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Mell Wright Evans (1855-1906) was a daughter of De Quille. She was married to Frank Algerman Evans (born 1852).

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Louisa G. Wright Stevens (born 1843) was a younger sister of De Quille. She was married to Frank W. Stevens.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes clippings from the San Francisco Chronicle related to mining engineer Philip Deidesheimer (1832-1916).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter of introduction for De Quille to Harper & Brothers publishers.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Unsigned letter, based on its contents, it is possibly by Rollin Mallory Daggett (1831-1901), editor-in-chief of the Territorial Enterprise newspaper in Virginia City, Nevada, 1873-1878.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Elizabeth Emmeline Brewster Scribner (born 1837) was the wife of Eben Scribner (circa 1840-1894), a mining amalgamator in Dayton, Nevada.

did.unittitle: Mack, Effie Mona, to Morris, Irma Evans
Morris, Irma Evans, to Mack, Effie Mona
Tilton, Cecil G., to Morris, Irma Evans

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writings by De Quille and others.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is organized into three subseries: Notebook, Drafts, and Writings by Others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Comprised chiefly of aphorisms and ideas for articles and stories. Includes an autograph copy of a letter by Mark Twain in the hand of De Quille about telepathy, March 29, 1875, as well as a story, "An Alaskan Legend."

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title followed by notes and a drawing.

did.unittitle: "Golden Back-Bone of the World," autograph manuscript
"Golden Back-Bone of the World," untitled autograph manuscript
"Little Biggs and Old Bedrock," autograph manuscript

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Discussion of animal husbandry in the Washoe Valley, Nevada, including cattle and raising geese to produce foie gras.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Brief notes on a variety of subjects, including mining in California, contents of a proposed book, and translation of a French phrase.

did.unittitle: Unidentified, Transcription of quotes about De Quille

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Quotes by Charles Corwin Goodwin, Joseph Goodman, and Wells Drury

did.unittitle: Unidentified, Transcription of an excerpt about De Quille from Irving Stone, Men to Match My Mountains: The Opening of the Far West 1840-1900 (Garden City, New York: Doubleday & Co., 1956.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs collected by De Quille and his family.

did.unittitle: J. B. Blanchard & Co., Portrait of Dan De Quille

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: James Brainard Blanchard (1837-1903) owned and operated the J. B. Blanchard & Co. in Los Angeles, California, circa 1880-1902.

did.unittitle: Werts, Perry D., Portrait of Dan De Quille

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Perry D. Werts (1857-1916) was a photographer in Iowa City, Iowa.

did.unittitle: Gravesite of De Quille in Oak Ridge Cemetery, West Liberty, Iowa

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series IV is organized into two subseries: Ephemera and Newspaper Clippings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ephemera collected and created by De Quille.

did.unittitle: Ticket to a clam-bake at Katama in Edgartown, Massachusetts

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by topic followed by oversize clippings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Newspaper clippings collected by De Quille and his heirs. The bulk of the clippings document topics related to Alaska, economics, and scientific subjects, with smaller quantities of clippings about other topics.
